statement.p: Real eigenvalues of A are defined as the real numbers \lambda such that (A-\lambda I_n)x = 0 has a nonzero real solution x. Explain why eigenvalues are precisely the real roots of \det(A-\lambda I_n), the characteristic polynomial of A. What do nonreal roots of \det(A-\lambda I_n) correspond to?
Why do eigenvalues of a triangular matrix (a_{ij}) are its entries on the main diagonal, that is, a_{11}, \cdots , a_{nn}? Is this true for non-triangular matrix?
Give an example of an upper triangular 4 \times 4 matrix A such that 0 is its only eigenvalue and its eigenspace E_0 is 1-dimensional.
Explain how to express \det(A) in terms of eigenvalues of A. Can a real 9 \times 9 matrix has a nonreal eigenvalue of multiplicity 5?
Using facts about determinants, justify the following fact: if A is an n \times n matrix, then A and A^T have the same characteristic polynomial.

[MIT OCW] Are the following statements true or false?
If A is invertible and \lambda is an eigenvalue of A, then \dfrac{1}{\lambda} is an eigenvalue of A\inv.
Let A be a real skew-symmetric n \times n matrix, i.e., A^T = -A. If \lambda is an eigenvalue of A, then so is -\lambda.

ol.li: True. If Ax=\lambda x, then x = \lambda A\inv x and A\inv x = \dfrac{1}{\lambda}x.
True. \det(A-\lambda I) = \det((A=\lambda I)^T) = \det(A^T - \lambda I) \quad = \det(-A-\lambda I) = (-1)^n \det(A+\lambda I)
